title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. SEC. 102. CHIMAYO WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM FEASIBILITY STUDY. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, "study area" means the Santa Cruz River Valley in the Espanola Basin, "system" refers to a water supply system, and "Town" is Chimayo, New Mexico. The Secretary will conduct a study with state and local authorities to determine the feasibility of the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary will conduct a feasibility study for the Chimayo Water Supply System in cooperation with state and local authorities. The study will determine the feasibility of constructing a water supply system including transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico. The system may operate in connection with the Espanola Water Filtration Facility. The Secretary will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in Chimayo, New Mexico, including transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. The study will consider various water supply options, including connection to regional sources, local sources, distributed sources in the town, and sources on adjacent Bureau of Land Management land. Reusing or recycling water from local or regional sources will also be considered. The Espanola Water Filtration Facility will explore options for water supply, including regional, local, distributed, and Bureau of Land Management sources. They will also consider reusing water, using alternative supplies like surface water or deep aquifer groundwater, and calculating total lifecycle costs. The Secretary will study alternative water supplies such as surface water, brackish water, nonpotable water, or deep aquifer groundwater. They will also determine the total lifecycle costs of the system, including operation, maintenance, replacement, treatment costs, and management costs. The study must be completed within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination of activities is required. The Secretary will study alternative water supplies and determine total lifecycle costs, including operation, maintenance, replacement, treatment, and management costs. The study must be completed within 3 years with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination of activities with other agencies is required. The Secretary will conduct a feasibility study on water resources for the Town, including accessing Bureau of Land Management land and drilling exploratory wells. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area through contracts with water authorities. A report on the feasibility study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion. The Secretary can enter contracts with water authorities in the study area to provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible individuals or entities. Assistance may include hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, and setting up pump stations and storage reservoirs. The Secretary may provide assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, setting up pump stations, and installing pipelines for residential water connections. Other eligible activities may also be supported as determined appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide assistance for activities like installing transmission and distribution pipelines for water delivery to residential connections, emergency water supply system engineering, design, and installation, and other eligible activities as determined appropriate. The Federal share of the cost for these activities will be 75 percent. SEC. 104. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $2,000,000 for section 102 for fiscal years 2005-2008 and $3,000,000 for section 103 for fiscal years 2005-2010. Limitation: funds under (a)(1) not for water infrastructure construction. The term "component" refers to water delivery infrastructure developments, while "facility" specifically denotes the Espanola water filtration facility. The term "Secretary" pertains to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary is tasked with providing financial assistance to Espanola, New Mexico, for constructing the Espanola water filtration facility to utilize imported water efficiently. The Secretary of the Interior will provide financial assistance to Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of an Espanola water filtration facility, including various projects to meet future water demands in the region. This includes the construction of presedimentation basins, an influent pump station, a pretreatment facility, and filtration facilities. The Secretary of the Interior will provide financial assistance to Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of a water filtration facility to meet future water demands. This includes presedimentation basins, influent pump station, pretreatment facility, filtration facilities, finished water storage, booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and potable water transmission lines. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of water facilities including pretreatment, filtration, storage, booster pump station, sludge dewatering, and transmission lines in Espanola, New Mexico, to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of water facilities in Espanola, New Mexico, to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Federal share of the total cost of the facility and the component shall not exceed 25 percent. Federal sponsors will provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of a water delivery infrastructure development for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos. The Federal share of the total cost shall not exceed 25 percent, and funds cannot be used for operation or maintenance. SEC. 203 authorizes $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
